topic.title: Configuring X.509 certificates
topic.shortdesc: This section explains how to configure X.509 certificates for TLS in Couchbase Server.

body.note: Choosing a root CA, the CA hierarchy, and obtaining a certificate from that CA chain to set up a Couchbase cluster are not within the scope of this document.

section.title: Certificate validity requirements for X.509 on Couchbase
section.p: Couchbase Server will accept an X.509 certificate as valid if it meets the following requirements:

ul.li: The certificate must be in available in .pem format
The current system time must fall between the times set in the certificate's properties valid from and valid to.
The node certificate must be designated for server authentication that is set in the optional field of the certificate's property enhanced key usage as Server Authentication.

Make sure that the certificate meets these requirements:
Common name: This can be a wildcard certificate (*.example.com), subject alternative name (SAN) certificate (example.com and example.net), a certificate with a node name, or an IP address.
Key length: 2048 bits or higher.

section.p: The certificate chain must be valid from the node certificate up to the root certificate, which can be verified using the OpenSSL validate certificate test.

section.title: Couchbase cluster certificate
section.p: The Couchbase cluster certificate is the root CA's public key. In the configuration steps shown in the following sections, ca.pem is the CA public key that should be configured in Couchbase as the cluster certificate.

When you load the cluster certificate into Couchbase, it is first checked to make sure it is a valid X.509 certificate. Next, if the per-node certificates are not signed by the cluster certificate, a warning is shown for each node during configuration. As the per-node certificates are updated, such that they are signed by the cluster certificate, the warning for each node goes away.

section.title: Per node certificate
section.p: The Couchbase cluster certificate is used to sign per node Couchbase certificates, each containing the following:

ul.li: The node private key (named server.key as shown in the configuration steps below)
The node public key certificate file (named server.pem as shown in the configuration steps below)
The certificate chain file based on the supported CA hierarchy (named chain.pem as shown in the configuration steps below)

section.title: Generating and configuring certificates in Couchbase
section.note: If your CA authority supports automatic generation of certificates, you can skip this step.
section.p: Here are the steps to help you generate an X.509 certificate for Couchbase Server using openSSL:

ol.li: Create a top-level directory called SSLCA and three sub-directories called root, int, and node.

p.codeblock: openssl genrsa -out ca.key 2048 openssl req -new -x509 -days 3650 -sha256 -key ca.key -out ca.pem -subj '/C=UA/O=My Company/CN=My Company Root CA'
openssl genrsa -out int.key 2048 openssl req -new -x509 -days 3650 -sha256 -key ca.key -out ca.pem -subj '/C=UA/O=My Company/CN=My Company Root CA'

ol.li:
Create the configuration file for OpenSSL:
cat <<EOF > v3_ca.ext subjectKeyIdentifier=hash authorityKeyIdentifier=keyid:always,issuer:always basicConstraints=CA:true EOF

Use the Certificate Signing Request (CSR) for the intermediate CA:
openssl x509 -req -in int.csr -CA ../root/ca.pem -CAkey ../root/ca.key -CAcreateserial -CAserial rootCA.srl \ -extfile v3_ca.ext -out int.pem -days 365 -sha256

Verify the intermediate-root chain:
openssl verify -CAfile ../root/ca.pem int.pem openssl x509 -in int.pem -text

li.b: Inside the node sub-directory (repeated for each node in the cluster):

p.codeblock: openssl genrsa -out pkey.key 2048 openssl req -new -key pkey.key -out pkey.csr -subj '/C=UA/O=My Company/CN=node_ip_address' openssl x509 -req -in pkey.csr -CA ../int/int.pem -CAkey ../int/int.key -CAcreateserial -CAserial \ intermediateCA.srl -out pkey.pem -days 365 -sha256

ol.li:
Verify the node-intermediate-root chain:
openssl verify -verbose pkey.pem openssl verify -untrusted ../int/int.pem pkey.pem openssl verify -untrusted ../int/int.pem -CAfile ../root/ca.pem pkey.pem

Generate a chain file (lowest goes first not including CA).
When a client application tries to verify a certificate signed by the intermediate CA, it must also verify the intermediate certificate against the root certificate. To complete the chain of trust, create a certificate chain to present to the application. To create the certificate chain file, concatenate the intermediate and root certificates together, beginning with the lowest one in the chain.
If you need to do this manually, you can use:
cat pkey.pem ../int/int.pem <possibly other intermediate CAs> > chain.pem
Here is an example: -----BEGIN CERTIFICATE----- Intermediate certificate 2 -----END CERTIFICATE----- -----BEGIN CERTIFICATE----- Intermediate certificate 1 -----END CERTIFICATE----- Do not include the root CAâ€™s public key certificate, and intermediate certificates that are not in the trust path in your chain file. Couchbase Server requires that you copy the private node key and chain file manually to the inbox folder on each node. The inbox folder should be in the Couchbase Data folder path. For example, on Mac OSX by default this is /Users/<username>/Library/Application\ Support/Couchbase/var/lib/couchbase/inbox/.
The chain file and private key file have to be in .pem format. The name of the private key file should be pkey.pem, and the name of the chain file should be chain.pem.

Copy the chain file and the key to the Couchbase folder Inbox:
cp chain.pem /Users/username/Library/Application\ Support/Couchbase/var/lib/couchbase/inbox/ cp pkey.key /Users/username/Library/Application\ Support/Couchbase/var/lib/couchbase/inbox/pkey.pem

Change permissions so that Couchbase can read:
cd /Users/username/Library/Application\ Support/Couchbase/var/lib/couchbase/inbox/ chmod 777 chain.pem chmod 777 pkey.pem

section.title: Setting up a cluster CA certificate

dd.codeblock: couchbase-cli ssl-manage -c [ip_of_any_cluster_node]:8091 -u[admin] -p[password] \ --upload-cluster-ca=[path to pem-encoded root certificate]

dlentry.dd: For example: couchbase-cli ssl-manage -c [ip_of_any_cluster_node]:8091 \ --upload-cluster-ca=./root/ca.pem \ -u Administrator -p password
